snippet.textDisplay:
A few years ago I noticed that drinking milk causes me to have acne.


I would go to school and my acne would flare up really bad within a week. I thought that maybe it was stress, but I wasn't all that stressed out.


As I got a little older I thought it could be my diet, but my diet was mostly the same during the summer as opposed to when I was at school except for I didn't drink milk while at home.


Once I quit drinking milk (at school I would bring water with me instead since water is expensive at my school compared to the price of milk) my acne got way better. I had less acne and when I did get acne the pimples were much smaller.


It wasn't a cure all, but milk definitely did cause acne despite whenever I would Google it every article would say that food doesn't cause acne then I would find some articles that would say that then they will say that the inflammation caused from those foods could cause it. Which annoyed me since consuming the food = pimples popping on your face even if it is inflammation it's still being caused by the food you are eating.
snippet.textOriginal:
A few years ago I noticed that drinking milk causes me to have acne.


I would go to school and my acne would flare up really bad within a week. I thought that maybe it was stress, but I wasn't all that stressed out.


As I got a little older I thought it could be my diet, but my diet was mostly the same during the summer as opposed to when I was at school except for I didn't drink milk while at home.


Once I quit drinking milk (at school I would bring water with me instead since water is expensive at my school compared to the price of milk) my acne got way better. I had less acne and when I did get acne the pimples were much smaller.


It wasn't a cure all, but milk definitely did cause acne despite whenever I would Google it every article would say that food doesn't cause acne then I would find some articles that would say that then they will say that the inflammation caused from those foods could cause it. Which annoyed me since consuming the food = pimples popping on your face even if it is inflammation it's still being caused by the food you are eating.

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who struggles with eating on and off, milk is such a life saver. snippet.textDisplay:
Some things this video didn't mention. A number of recent studies show a cardioprotective effect against cardiovascular disease. In contrast to the assumption that fat increases risk of cardiovascular disease. They also didn't mention centenarian studies, which show a high prevalence of dairy consumption among individuals over 100. Also, one of the main reasons why I drink milk is not just for the protein and b12, but for the dietary fat. In an effort to stay slim and reduce insulin resistance as I age, milk is kind of a cornerstone. As long as you stay away from milk with added sugar, like chocolate milk or american milk/walmart milk (why do the states add sugar to milk?). I'm on a low carb moderate fat diet in an effort to reduce my caloric intake and control my aging. And unlike carbs, milk will satiate you and make you feel full, meaning that you ultimately eat less overall.

In the future I believe dairy will become an important food source in the face of overpopulation, rising costs and food scarcity. Unlike soy or plant based milks, dairy doesn't have to be fortified. It pretty much contains all the nutrients a child or adult needs when struggling with malnutrition. The environmental impacts are a valid concern, but rather than eliminating a food source, my stance has always been that we need to correct the supply line rather than throwing it away by developing lab grown meat. A proof of concept that's already in development and would be much further along if not for political and public apprehension. And lab grown dairy would be an easy milestone in pursuit of that goal. Only one cell type contributes to the production of milk, and its a liquid, so resembling milk won't be an issue. And in a future where sources of protein are scarce, the economy is struggling, and most people in the world lack access to fortified foods or medicine, B12 deficiency, anemia, calcium deficiency, vitamin D deficiency, zinc deficiency and many more can all be treated with a glass of milk.

There's a reason why markets are being flooded with cheap carb heavy/nutrient poor cash crops, and its because these crops grow quickly and are easy to mass produce. But they're also the driving force of obesity in the world. Diets that are primarily high in carbs and nothing else. On an overpopulated earth, this will get worse despite occurring side by side with malnutrition. Lab grown dairy could potentially meet those needs without driving us closer to a mad max type scenario. And considering we're already passed the point of no return, avoiding climate change is no longer happening. We need to be prepared for the inevitable food scarcity that's going to come. Much like those ancient humans had an advantage over other groups with the availability of dairy in their diets, the future of humanity will depend on those who can produce lab grown meat/dairy in the face of climate change.
snippet.textOriginal:
Some things this video didn't mention. A number of recent studies show a cardioprotective effect against cardiovascular disease. In contrast to the assumption that fat increases risk of cardiovascular disease. They also didn't mention centenarian studies, which show a high prevalence of dairy consumption among individuals over 100. Also, one of the main reasons why I drink milk is not just for the protein and b12, but for the dietary fat. In an effort to stay slim and reduce insulin resistance as I age, milk is kind of a cornerstone. As long as you stay away from milk with added sugar, like chocolate milk or american milk/walmart milk (why do the states add sugar to milk?). I'm on a low carb moderate fat diet in an effort to reduce my caloric intake and control my aging. And unlike carbs, milk will satiate you and make you feel full, meaning that you ultimately eat less overall. 

In the future I believe dairy will become an important food source in the face of overpopulation, rising costs and food scarcity. Unlike soy or plant based milks, dairy doesn't have to be fortified. It pretty much contains all the nutrients a child or adult needs when struggling with malnutrition. The environmental impacts are a valid concern, but rather than eliminating a food source, my stance has always been that we need to correct the supply line rather than throwing it away by developing lab grown meat. A proof of concept that's already in development and would be much further along if not for political and public apprehension. And lab grown dairy would be an easy milestone in pursuit of that goal. Only one cell type contributes to the production of milk, and its a liquid, so resembling milk won't be an issue. And in a future where sources of protein are scarce, the economy is struggling, and most people in the world lack access to fortified foods or medicine, B12 deficiency, anemia, calcium deficiency, vitamin D deficiency, zinc deficiency and many more can all be treated with a glass of milk. 

There's a reason why markets are being flooded with cheap carb heavy/nutrient poor cash crops, and its because these crops grow quickly and are easy to mass produce. But they're also the driving force of obesity in the world. Diets that are primarily high in carbs and nothing else. On an overpopulated earth, this will get worse despite occurring side by side with malnutrition. Lab grown dairy could potentially meet those needs without driving us closer to a mad max type scenario. And considering we're already passed the point of no return, avoiding climate change is no longer happening. We need to be prepared for the inevitable food scarcity that's going to come. Much like those ancient humans had an advantage over other groups with the availability of dairy in their diets, the future of humanity will depend on those who can produce lab grown meat/dairy in the face of climate change.

snippet.textDisplay: Kurzgesagt clearly has an agenda and is not to be trusted. There is what they do: 1. They use two persuasion tactics. They report to "there are conflicting findings" tactic which is fostered by industry sponsored biased research. 2. Overgeneralize, e.g. milk is not associated with X (e.g. specific type of cancer) therefore it is not cancerogenic. 3. They draw conclusions contradicting their own points (e.g. "milk is safe for majority of people", it is not since majority of people are lactose intolerant). 4. They shift the debate to a question easier to argue for, in the title they ask if milk is poison or healthy, they mostly argue against poison hypotheses, reject it and imply the healthy. This is inconsistent with their own statement that milk has no advantages above alternative drinks.

snippet.textDisplay:
Not only quantity but you should also consider quality . therefore , if you drink milk make sure you always drink A2 type milk and not A1


Heres why :
Protein is made of no. Of peptides, and peptides are made of amino acids. So, in A1 milk chain of amino acid there is histidine at 67 position of amino acid chain while in A2 milk there is proline.
But histidine form loose bond with its adjacent amino acid that is 66 , so there is release of another half which is called beta casinomorphine(BCM). Now this BCM is not digested properly in our guts.
So studied, said that it result in development of diseases like autism, heart blockage, type 1 diabetes, and schizophrenia over a longer period of time.
While there is no release of BCM in A2 milk as it form strong bond with its adjacent amino acid . And it is easy to digest.

snippet.textDisplay:
So, I don't know if anyone cares about what I'm going to write or if anyone will even read this but, as owner of a medium sized cattle farm based on milk production this is how things actually work (in Romania, based on European Union laws).
1. In this type of farms, small, medium (about 150 animals), their life is pretty normal, is far from suffering. They are not kept in a building where they eat, produce milk and born viels/calfs (cows baby's, i don't know how they are called in english) because its much more expensive and harder, so their life resumes at 3 hours (1 and a half hours is the morning and the same in the afternoon) in a building where they are milked (around 10 minutes per cow, but they have to stay more to wait for the others, and meanwhile they eat extra food) and for the rest of the day they stay outside, almost completely free (a large field full of grass where they live similar to wild animals, the only diffrence is that they are protected from possible predators)
2. They come to get milked all by themself. They are not beaten or things like that. Its true, like you could do to a child, they are getting bribed with products that are considered by them as sweets, some extra food that you love eating (its not unhealty, its based on corn or wheat). There is just this small sacrifice, that they are annoyed by the thing that milks them for like 10 minutes (it doesn't hurt, its just annoying)
3. About the productivity and them getting killed after that, its true but there is need for some explanation. When this happens the cows are already pretty old (usually more than 10 years), and they can't keep it up with the herd not even in moving, not only giving milk. When a wild animals reach this point they are usually getting caught by predators and die, so its pretty much the same thing but they don't get bitten meanwhile, just a quick death. When they die younger, it happens cause of a tragedy, like breaking a bone or getting really sick, in which they can't be saved (belive me, even if you care only about money you don't what them to die, because you lose more than you win)
4. About children, sadly, this is the bad part. When they are born, after a short period (few days) they are taken away from there mom, but they are kept is front of them (its the place next to where they eat). They can still see each other for the time spent in the building by the mother but I know, its not the same.
5. About continuing impregnation that's false is our case (in large farms it happens, true) but in medium and small ones no. After the birth it takes a long period until the cows milk is reaching low amounts. Even after that, they are inpregnated only after they are getting horny (its sound weird, but you get it), its still natural, they are not forced!
6. About polution, in this case there is nothing extra we could do about it, on the part of air polution, for the others are strict laws. The only way is reducing their population. The only thing I could think is what if the large farms could do. From what I know, most of the gas they are eliminating is methane. What if we could gatter it somehow and then used it?
snippet.textOriginal:
So, I don't know if anyone cares about what I'm going to write or if anyone will even read this but, as owner of a medium sized cattle farm based on milk production this is how things actually work (in Romania, based on European Union laws).
1. In this type of farms, small, medium (about 150 animals), their life is pretty normal, is far from suffering. They are not kept in a building where they eat, produce milk and born viels/calfs (cows baby's, i don't know how they are called in english) because its much more expensive and harder, so their life resumes at 3 hours (1 and a half hours is the morning and the same in the afternoon) in a building where they are milked (around 10 minutes per cow, but they have to stay more to wait for the others, and meanwhile they eat extra food) and for the rest of the day they stay outside, almost completely free (a large field full of grass where they live similar to wild animals, the only diffrence is that they are protected from possible predators)
2. They come to get milked all by themself. They are not beaten or things like that. Its true, like you could do to a child, they are getting bribed with products that are considered by them as sweets, some extra food that you love eating (its not unhealty, its based on corn or wheat). There is just this small sacrifice, that they are annoyed by the thing that milks them for like 10 minutes (it doesn't hurt, its just annoying)
3. About the productivity and them getting killed after that, its true but there is need for some explanation. When this happens the cows are already pretty old (usually more than 10 years), and they can't keep it up with the herd not even in moving, not only giving milk. When a wild animals reach this point they are usually getting caught by predators and die, so its pretty much the same thing but they don't get bitten meanwhile, just a quick death. When they die younger, it happens cause of a tragedy, like breaking a bone or getting really sick, in which they can't be saved (belive me, even if you care only about money you don't what them to die, because you lose more than you win)
4. About children, sadly, this is the bad part. When they are born, after a short period (few days) they are taken away from there mom, but they are kept is front of them (its the place next to where they eat). They can still see each other for the time spent in the building by the mother but I know, its not the same. 
5. About continuing impregnation that's false is our case (in large farms it happens, true) but in medium and small ones no. After the birth it takes a long period until the cows milk is reaching low amounts. Even after that, they are inpregnated only after they are getting horny (its sound weird, but you get it), its still natural, they are not forced!
6. About polution, in this case there is nothing extra we could do about it, on the part of air polution, for the others are strict laws. The only way is reducing their population. The only thing I could think is what if the large farms could do. From what I know, most of the gas they are eliminating is methane. What if we could gatter it somehow and then used it?

snippet.textDisplay:
* uses mostly dairy industry funded studies *

In reality dairy is very bad for health, and the fact that so many people who quit drinking/eating it almost immediately see positive changes in their health, speaks volumes. If you look at studies that are not funded by the industry, you see that is directly linked to many health problems and diseases, prostate cancer for example.

" No significant amount of hormones in milk "
There is 300 times more natural hormones in cow's milk than in human milk. When humans drink the stuff that is designed to turn a calf quickly into a 650 kg ruminant, no good things will follow. Dairy causes many hormonal problems in humans, such as acne, infertility, premature puberty, menstrual cramps and skin problems/diseases (+cancers). It also causes inflammation, asthma and osteoporosis (countries with highest dairy consumption have the highest rates of osteoporosis, and vice versa).
Calcium from plants absorbs much better than from dairy.

People are not lactose intolerant: we are simply not designed to drink milk after we stop breastfeeding from our mothers. After that our bodies stop producing the enzyme which breaks down lactase, which is a sign we need milk no more.

Most importantly, we have absolutely no right to steal milk from the babies (calves) it belongs to. No other animal in nature drinks milk as an adult: milk is always just baby food. Should be common sense.
Dairy industry rips the babies from their mothers immediately after birth, so we could drink their milk instead.

Dairy is also very bad for the planet, it takes 10 times more natural resources to produce it compared to oat, soy or hemp milk for example.

Most importantly, we have absolutely no right to steal milk from the babies (calves) it belongs to. No other animal in nature drinks milk as an adult: milk is always just baby food. Should be common sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
5:55 "Milk, no matter if it comes from mothers, cows, sheep, goats, or camels[...]"

Cows, sheep, goats, and camels are ALSO mothers! They produce milk for their babies. Since we do not need it we should not keep other animals lactating their entire lives in order to feed us.

snippet.textDisplay: Some good stuff in this video sure,  but I'm concerned that the vast majority of studies cited are industry funded. It'd just be nice to see more peer reviewed studies cited. I think that's when you get a rounded answer to most things. Apparently Industry funded studies are usually 4-8x more likely to find an outcome in there favour(seems obvious I guess). We need more rounded research before we can find the definite conclusion to the question.
